Having oneself already been free from delusion, one is also able to speak for other individuals the Dharma of subduing delusion;
Having oneself already been free from defilements, one is also able to speak for others the Dharma of subduing all afflictions;
One does not see those with the afflictions of greed, anger, and delusion as inferior, nor those free from the afflictions of greed, anger, and delusion as superior.
Why is this?
Because that bodhisattva, through the realization of the pure Dharma gate of the non-dual Dharma realm,
such a Dharma realm is the realm of greed, anger, and delusion;
such a Dharma realm is the realm of freedom from defilements.
Therefore, the Dharma realm and all dharmas mutually penetrate each other. The Dharma realm is the dharmas, and the dharmas are the Dharma realm, pervading everywhere.
If one knows the realm of self, one knows the Dharma realm, because the Dharma realm and the realm of self are non-dual.
Why is this?
Because I am pure, the dharma realm is pure. In this way, all dharmas are pure.
It is radiant and accommodating, yet without accommodation, because it is free from all characteristics and has no characteristics.
It is unestablished, just like space, and is called unobstructed wisdom.
By means of unobstructed wisdom, one understands all dharmas without obstruction. This is the bodhisattva's practice of wisdom, which is like space.
Good sons!
What is the Buddha's approval of the bodhisattvas' recollection of the Buddha?
It is as follows:
Recollecting the undefiled precepts is the Buddha's recollection of the precepts;
The equality and non-dispersal of all dharmas is the Buddha's recollection of concentration;
The non-discrimination of all dharmas is the Buddha's recollection of wisdom;
The mind that does not abide in duality is the Buddha's recollection of liberation;
Not being attached to omniscience is the Buddha's recollection of the knowledge and vision of liberation;
The immobility of the equality of the three times is the Buddha's recollection of power;
Not dwelling in any defilements, this is the fearless Buddha-mindfulness.
Thus, one should be mindful of all the merits possessed by the Buddha's body, which are all Buddha-mindfulness. The Dharma realm is equal and without discrimination.

Furthermore, in Buddha-mindfulness, one is mindful of the pure nature of the Buddha's form. By seeing the pure nature of form, non-thought wisdom is attained. Up to feelings, perceptions, mental formations, and consciousness, by seeing the pure nature of consciousness, non-thought wisdom is attained.
Thus, the twelve sense bases and eighteen elements are also like this.
By the wisdom of the intrinsic nature of all dharmas, the most excellent wisdom is able to detach from all conceptual thoughts and all views.
Detaching from such, knowing form to be without defilement, and mindfulness to be without defilement, this is called the Buddha's approval of Buddha-mindfulness.
Furthermore, in Buddha-mindfulness, one is mindful of the Buddha's walking, standing, sitting, and lying down, and all his dignified deportment, without giving rise to attachment;
They do not give rise to attachment to the Buddha's teaching of the Dharma or to the Buddha's silent meditation, nor do they attach to mindfulness or non-mindfulness.
Why is this?
The Buddha has no mindfulness, no intention, is neither form nor characteristics, neither Dharma nor non-Dharma, because all characteristics and conceptual thoughts do not manifest.
Good man!
This is called the Buddha's approval of mindfulness of the Buddha.
Good man!

Dharma is called tranquility, because the mind, thought, and consciousness are not defiled, and thus there is no mindfulness of the Dharma that follows.ğŸ”½Dharma is called signless, because there is no consciousness that follows characteristics in the Dharma, and thus there is no mindfulness of the Dharma that follows.
Dharma is called unconditioned, because there is no establishment or abiding in the Dharma, and thus there is no mindfulness of the Dharma that follows.

Furthermore, if one contemplates the Dharma without interruption, without giving rise to the notion of dharmas, one enters the correct stage and realizes the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas. Contemplating that all dharmas are originally unborn and there is nothing to be realized, this is the place realized by all learners, non-learners, pratyekabuddhas, and bodhisattvas.
In this way, all the liberated dharmas realized by the sages also have no self-nature.
This is called the bodhisattva's recollection of the Dharma approved by the Buddha.
Good son!
How does the bodhisattva recollect the Sangha approved by the Buddha?
The Sangha is unconditioned, and it cannot be created by fabrication, yet it has no manifest physical, verbal, or mental actions, but rather has something to be practiced through designation.
This unconditioned Sangha abides apart from designation and transcends all verbal discussions.
Good son!
This is called the recollection of the Sangha approved by the Buddha.
Good son!
What is the bodhisattvas' mindfulness of relinquishment approved by the Buddha?
It is the relinquishment of all relied-upon resources, and the relinquishment of the Dharma without anything to relinquish. This is called the supreme relinquishment.

In all dharmas there is no grasping, no relinquishing, and nothing to seek. There is no mental activity, nor is there a lack of mental activity. It does not abide in consciousness, nor does it give rise to the mind, because the abiding mind is non-existent.
This is called the mindfulness of relinquishment approved by the Buddha.
Furthermore, the bodhisattvas' mindfulness of relinquishment is to dedicate the practiced merit towards the wisdom of omniscience, and not to see enlightenment as an object of mindfulness.
Why is this?
Because omniscience and mindfulness are non-dual by nature.
Good man!
Such Dharma wisdom is called the bodhisattvas' mindfulness of relinquishment approved by the Buddha.
Good man!
What is the bodhisattvas' mindfulness of precepts approved by the Buddha?

The precepts are called unconditioned, undefiled, unobstructed, and permanently ceasing effort. They accomplish all prohibitions, are without consciousness, without characteristics, and also do not dwell in the mind to create samÄdhi, are the supreme basis, and are also the fundamental source of generating pure wisdom.
Free from the characteristics of play and liberation, and also without the characteristics of the two kinds of discrimination.

Praised by the wise, without any manifest form, able to extinguish afflictions and also without establishment, peacefully following practice, and also without any countermeasures to all discriminations.
Bodhisattvas are always without defilement in such types of precepts, which is called the bodhisattvas' mindfulness of the precepts approved by the Buddha.
Good sons!
